syllabus.title: Relations and Functions
syllabus.overview: This chapter extends the Class 11 concepts to classify relations (reflexive, symmetric, transitive) and functions (injective, surjective, bijective), framing the foundation for calculus.
keyTopics: Types of Relations (Empty, Universal, Reflexive, Symmetric, Transitive)

formulas.name: Reflexive
formulas.formula: (a, a) ∈ R for every a ∈ A

formulas.name: Transitive
formulas.formula: (a, b) ∈ R and (b, c) ∈ R ⇒ (a, c) ∈ R

examTips: Proving a relation is an Equivalence Relation is a guaranteed question. You must explicitly prove it is Reflexive, Symmetric, and Transitive.
To prove a function is NOT one-one, finding a single counter-example (e.g., f(-1) = f(1) = 1 for f(x)=x²) is sufficient.
Pay very close attention to the domain and codomain given (e.g., N → N vs R → R) as it completely changes whether a function is onto.

syllabus.title: Inverse Trigonometric Functions
syllabus.overview: Explores the inverses of standard trigonometric functions by restricting their domains to make them bijective, focusing on their principal value branches.
examTips: Memorize the Principal Value Branch for all 6 inverse trigonometric functions. The most common mistake is writing answers outside this branch.
Questions asking to evaluate sin⁻¹(sin(2π/3)) require bringing the angle back into the principal branch before cancelling sin and sin⁻¹.

syllabus.title: Matrices
syllabus.overview: Introduces matrices as ordered rectangular arrays of numbers or functions, covering matrix algebra and special types of matrices.
examTips: Remember that matrix multiplication is NOT commutative (AB ≠ BA generally).
Writing a matrix as the sum of a symmetric and a skew-symmetric matrix (½(A+A') + ½(A-A')) is a frequent long-answer question.
Be extremely careful with arithmetic signs during matrix multiplication.

syllabus.title: Determinants
syllabus.overview: Connects to matrices by assigning a unique real number to every square matrix. It is essential for solving systems of linear equations and finding matrix inverses.
keyTopics: Area of a Triangle using Determinants
Adjoint and Inverse of a Matrix
Solving Systems of Linear Equations (Matrix Method)
examTips: Solving a system of 3 linear equations using the Matrix method (X = A⁻¹B) is almost guaranteed to be a 5-mark or 6-mark question. Practice finding the adjoint accurately.
Remember the checkerboard sign pattern (+ - +) when expanding determinants or finding cofactors.
Use determinants to prove three points are collinear (Area = 0).

syllabus.title: Continuity and Differentiability
syllabus.overview: Bridges the limits from Class 11 to formal calculus, defining when a function is continuous, and introducing advanced differentiation techniques.
keyTopics: Continuity at a point and on an interval
examTips: Finding unknown constants (like 'k') to make a piecewise function continuous is a very common question type.
Always use Logarithmic Differentiation when you see a variable raised to the power of a variable (e.g., x^sin(x)).
For second-order derivatives in parametric form, remember that d²y/dx² is NOT simply (d²y/dt²)/(d²x/dt²). You must differentiate dy/dx with respect to x.

syllabus.title: Application of Derivatives
syllabus.overview: Applies differentiation to real-world physical problems, graphing, and optimization (finding maximum/minimum values).

formulas.name: Second Derivative Test
formulas.formula: If f''(c) < 0 ⇒ Local Max; If f''(c) > 0 ⇒ Local Min

examTips: An Optimization word problem (e.g., finding the maximum volume of a cone inscribed in a sphere) will almost certainly be the hardest 6-mark question on the paper. Practice converting geometric relationships into a single-variable function.
For Rate of Change problems, write down what is given (e.g., dV/dt = 10) and what is asked (e.g., dr/dt at r=5) before differentiating.
Draw a number line to test intervals for Increasing/Decreasing functions.

syllabus.title: Integrals
syllabus.overview: Introduces integration as the inverse process of differentiation, covering various techniques to evaluate both indefinite and definite integrals.

formulas.name: By Parts (ILATE rule)
formulas.formula: ∫u v dx = u ∫v dx - ∫(u' ∫v dx) dx

examTips: The property ∫[a,b] f(x) dx = ∫[a,b] f(a+b-x) dx is nicknamed the 'King Property' because it is used to solve 80% of tricky definite integral questions.
Use the ILATE rule (Inverse, Logarithmic, Algebraic, Trig, Exponential) to choose 'u' (first function) for Integration by Parts.
Don't forget the '+ C' for indefinite integrals. You will lose marks.

syllabus.title: Application of Integrals
syllabus.overview: Applies the concepts from Chapter 7 specifically to find the geometric area bounded by curves, lines, the x-axis, or the y-axis.
keyTopics: Area bounded by a Curve and a Line
examTips: Drawing a rough sketch of the curves is MANDATORY. You must correctly identify the points of intersection to set your integration limits.
If a curve dips below the x-axis, integral evaluates to negative. Take the absolute value for Area.
Equations of Parabolas and Circles are the most frequently used boundaries.

syllabus.title: Differential Equations
syllabus.overview: Combines differentiation and integration to solve equations containing derivatives, which model dynamic real-world systems.
keyTopics: Order and Degree of a D.E.
Methods of Solving: Linear D.E. (Integrating Factor)
examTips: To find the 'Degree', the equation must be a polynomial in its derivatives. (e.g., sin(dy/dx) means degree is not defined).
The Integrating Factor (I.F.) method for solving Linear Differential Equations is a very common 4-mark question.
For Homogeneous equations, always use the substitution y = vx, which makes dy/dx = v + x(dv/dx).

syllabus.title: Vector Algebra
syllabus.overview: Introduces quantities with both magnitude and direction. This chapter forms the foundation for 3D Geometry and physics applications.
keyTopics: Vectors and Scalars, Magnitude and Direction
Types of Vectors, Addition, Scalar Multiplication
examTips: Questions asking for a 'unit vector perpendicular to both a and b' require calculating the cross product, and then dividing by its magnitude.
Use the dot product to find the angle between two vectors.
The projection of vector a on vector b is (a·b) / |b|.

syllabus.title: Three Dimensional Geometry
syllabus.overview: Applies vector algebra to study the mathematics of Lines and Planes in 3D space. It involves visualizing geometric intersections.
keyTopics: Direction Cosines and Ratios of a Line
Equation of a Line in Space (Vector & Cartesian)
Shortest Distance between Two Skew Lines
examTips: The 'Shortest Distance between two Skew Lines' is one of the most frequently asked 5/6 mark questions in the entire syllabus. Master the formula.
Always convert Cartesian equations to standard form before extracting direction ratios. For example, if you see (3-x)/2, rewrite it as (x-3)/(-2).
Remember that cos²α + cos²β + cos²γ = 1 (where α, β, γ are angles made with axes).

syllabus.title: Linear Programming
syllabus.overview: A largely standalone, practical chapter dealing with optimizing a linear objective function subject to linear inequality constraints (mostly resource allocation).
keyTopics: Graphical Method of Solution for two variables

formulas.name: Corner Point Theorem
formulas.formula: Optimal value always occurs at corner points of feasible region

examTips: This is an 'easy marks' chapter. The formulation of the equations from the word problem is 50% of the marks; the graph is the other 50%.
Always shade the feasible region neatly and clearly calculate coordinates for all corner points.
If the feasible region is UNBOUNDED, calculating the maximum/minimum requires checking if the open half-plane intersects the feasible region.

syllabus.title: Probability
syllabus.overview: Advances Class 11 probability into conditional events, introducing the highly important Bayes' Theorem and random variables.
keyTopics: Random Variable and its Probability Distribution
examTips: Bayes' Theorem is guaranteed to appear as a 4, 5, or 6 mark Case Study question. Practice defining your events (E1, E2, A) clearly.
Conditional Probability problems often start with 'Given that...'. The event that has already occurred is placed in the denominator condition P(X|Given).
Sum of all probabilities in a probability distribution table must exactly equal 1.
